Posts.Content: Session went well but after being home 2 hours started vomiting, for 12 hours. Finally rang hospital who admitted me and got sorted. Moral of the tale don't wait to ring hospital for help. If you vomit within 12 hours of chemo ring hospital immediately before you become dehydrated like I did.now home. 2 days later with strict instructions and a plan to contact hospital immediately if vomiting recurs. Gail x
Posts.Title: First FEC chemo

Posts.Content: Yes the injections do seem frightening but I'm sure someone you know could help. It's a tiny retractable needle and they're so easy to use. Try not to worry it will work out. My hubby is petrified of needles but after watching me do them he has offered to have a go.i had my first chemo 2 nd Jan and started my injections 3days ago. Hope all goes well, will be thinking about you. X Gail
Posts.Title: First FEC chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks for reply. I am keeping a diary came in use when the onc asked for more detailed info. Hubby got arrowroot biscuits, I remembered those from morning sickness days. I have been promised that next time will be better and will be given more suitable anti emetics. Thanks Dorothee, I always find your posts so caring, useful and heartfelt. Gail x
Posts.Title: First FEC chemo

Posts.Content: I agree, Good News is just as important as bad. How lovely for both of you at this emotional time of year. Gail x
Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: I agree, Good News is just as important as bad. How lovely for both of you at this emotional time of year. Gail x
Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome. Hope you find this site as useful as I have. I had a similar diagnosis to you in Oct 2012 and had surgery and am now in the middle of chemo. One day at a time is good. Every day is different. I hope you make your daughters Mothers Day service, take tissues I'm sure you'll be emotional. Thank you for the positive vibes. Hope your surgery goes well and you make a good recovery. X
Posts.Title: Taking it one day at a time

Posts.Content: Hope all goes well will be thinking about you. The staff will be so caring and professional around you. I'm a theatre nurse and I went for surgery to the theatres where I work. Even I was anxious but I worried uneccesarily. They were all marvellous. It will be all done before you know it and you'll be on your way home. Gail x
Posts.Title: Still very anxious about surgery tommorow

Posts.Content: Hi Glen, welcome, keep posting and reading on here, it will certainly help you and you will learn more than you thought possible. X
Posts.Title: For my mum!!

Posts.Content: You've made the right decision, going in to get answers to your questions and to get some relief for your symptoms.It's going to be a long and difficult night for you. I hope you manage to get some sleep and rest tonight. Will be thinking of you.xxx
Posts.Title: Going to ward tomorrow

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing what a mess, it's bad enough dealing with breast cancer without having a fights your hands with the benefits agency and their underlings, or should I say the agencies they have farmed their work out to. What can you say to help? Nothing. It's sad to see how the Government is wasting our money and has become a faceless, uncaring body. Having just completed claim forms for ESA because my SSP has run out, I will wait to see what my experience is. Good luck and I hope the letters stop soon.
Posts.Title: A warning for those of you involved in work programmes

Posts.Content: We are all here going through this with you. I think most of us are scared too but somehow we are all going to get through this together. There is no right or wrong way to react . You will get stronger as you learn more about your treatment. The waiting is the worst but once you get on the roller coaster it really does get easier as you start to take some positive action towards removing this unwanted cancer from your body. I have breast cancer and am in the middle of chemo after having surgery. I'm still scared but am so busy having treatment I don't always have time to think about it. Everyone is here to help, your BC nurse, surgeon, oncologist, there will be lots of information available and plenty of sympathetic ears, especially on this site. Make good use of it, hope all goes well for you x
Posts.Title: Scared off breast cancer

Posts.Content: Keep in mind, all the statistics are based on old treatments and they are improving all the time. NO ONE knows exactly what will happen to each one of us. Enjoy every minute with your lovely children and watch them grow in your love.Don't be counting down continuously. No one can predict an accurate outcome for any of us.
Posts.Title: its spread so scared

Posts.Content: Hi Lindy, welcome we're all reluctant members but we seem to get on very we'll and support each other. The majority of my questions have been answered on this site, especially the practical ones. I'm just at the beginning of chemo after surgery in November. Day 12 of 1 st chemo. All I can say is it was steep learning curve and friends on here have been there for me.We all have moments of tears just think of it as a form of release. Hope surgery, treatment go well for you. Gail x
Posts.Title: Hello, I'm a newbie

Posts.Content: That's excellent news.I did wonder how you were getting on. Yet another branch of hope for those struggling with seromas. This site is excellent. I learn something on here every day. Best wishes for 2013. X
Posts.Title: My Seroma won't go away

Posts.Content: Oh you are having a tough time. I really feel for you. I can only remember how painful the axillary clearance was and the subsequent drain, so can't imagine how painful your seroma is. I do hope it settles soon. Thinking of you x
Posts.Title: My Seroma won't go away

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne , we all agree the waiting is terrible, and sometimes you hear of someone who appears to get an apt foe chemo before you. Believe me it will happen and once you start treatment it's like a roller coaster. I'm halfway through FEC-T chemo and can't believe how quick it has gone, and son will be thinking about radiotherapy. You will get an apt usually about 6-8 weeks post op. I waited 7 weeks and was starting to panic and kept pestering the BC nurses, they must have been sick of me. hope all goes well for you Gail x
Posts.Title: Waiting....and waiting.... doesn't it cause more stress?

Posts.Content: You good friends have put into words how I feel. So miserable ungrateful tearful, after everything everyone is doing to try to help me get through this. I still don't feel like any of this is real. I'm not as far on in treatment as you just had 1st chemo on 2nd Jan. got a long way to go yet, how on earth did you get so far? I will do it but I think there is going to be a few tears and tantrums on the way. Gail x
Posts.Title: Really fed up

Posts.Content: Nothing prepares you for the cancer chat from the Consultant. I had the news at the end of October and still haven't really accepted it. Just feels like I'm on this roller caster of surgery treatment hospital appointments etc. I just hope I'm still sane when I finally hop off. Definitely take someone with you to the appointments. My mind went totally blank and I couldn't remember any of my pre prepared questions. That's where you can use the breast care nurses. You'll receive a large pack of info too. Hope all goes well for. Use this site there some very knowledgeable BC friends on here. X
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - feeling lost

Posts.Content: Hi Claire, it is extremely difficult making the choice and it seems like you havent even got used to the idea that you have cancer, and you don't feel ill anyway do you? I'm in a similar position except my lymph nodes were affected so I've been advised to have chemo. Yes I was blinded by the statistics as to what benefit I would get. In the end I asked the oncologist what he would do if he was in my shoes and he said he would have the chemo because I was young (56 ?). Anyway it has to be your choice, it's unfortunate that you don't have much time to consider all the facts.I only saw the oncologist last week and I'm having my first chemo next week. Watch this space .. Good luck in deciding.
Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: Wendy will you be having your surgery straight after the Tax.
Posts.Title: End of FEC Taxotare in 2 weeks. What to expect?

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome, many of your fears , worries and concerns will be resolved on this site. I hope you find it as useful and supportive as I have. X
Posts.Title: New to the group

Posts.Content: Finished FEC this week. Wasn't wonderful but I made it. What do I expect with Taxotare, more of the same? When I had my 2nd FEC the patient in the next char having her 1st Taxotare had a severe reaction and had to be admitted. It scared me. Anyone else know about this effect?
Posts.Title: End of FEC Taxotare in 2 weeks. What to expect?

Posts.Content: Like you I can't wait to go swimming. I've just started chemo so reckon I might be able to go on a good day? Have got fairly good movement back in my arm and shoulder. Will just lie in water and float anyway if cant do much else. Hope you enjoy your swim Dorothee. Gail x
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: Like you I can't wait to go swimming. I've just started chemo so reckon I might be able to go on a good day? Have got fairly good movement back in my arm and shoulder. Will just lie in water and float anyway if cant do much else. Hope you enjoy your swim Dorothee. Gail x
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: Good point, when do you say I HAD cancer and not I have cancer? I usually say I'm having treatment for cancer but then friends say didn't the surgery get it all? So surely it's gone. Not that simple is it? No one seems to be helping with emotional side of things, except my GP. I am thinking of joining a local BC group but haven't made it yet either due to hospital admissions, appointments or feeling lousy, and my nearest group is 22 miles away. Feel pretty cr--- y just now with hair loss and body image. It's no picnic this BC lark is it? I will get this sorted though and get on with living I'm usually the one who helps everyone else with their problems and keeps them going.
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome, there will be plenty of support on this forum just keep asking the questions. There is always someone to help. We'll be there for you. Xxx
Posts.Title: hello

Posts.Content: Made it ,it's my Breast cancer anniversary. I've had WLE and Axillary clearance, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, Tamoxifen. What a huge thanks I owe to all those brave souls who trialled, the chemo and radio. THANK YOU. There is life after breast cancer, no it's not perfect but I'm making the most of it. My house may not be a s tidy, but I'm enjoying LIFE. YOU CAN ALL DO IT TOO. XXX
Posts.Title: One year on- after BC

Posts.Content: Inspirational yes we do need a like button. Will think of this in my difficult times during treatment. Thank you for posting such positive news. X
Posts.Title: Turning Corners and a Bit of Inspiration :-)

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with breast cancer late Oct and had a wide local excision and sentinel node biopsy within 2 weeks. 2 weeks later I was told there was cancer in a lymph node so then had an axillary clearance. That was 5 weeks ago and after all the initial hurried surgery I feel forgotten. I'm going to see the oncologist this Friday but expect a few tests before treatment starts. I want to get on with things now, but it seems to be dragging.I also feel isolated.What happens next and when?
Posts.Title: jessica1

Posts.Content: Hi there, my oncologist did a report for my employer recommending I need 2 months off work post radiotherapy to ' recover my stamina'. I think someone said earlier, since when did occupational health nurses become experts on radiotherapy and oncology? Speak to your oncologist. Good luck with treatment
Posts.Title: Time off work

Posts.Content: Hi, I've had changed heart rhythm during chemo too. I have mentioned it to my oncologist but he didn't seem concerned. I had an ECG and that was normal. I know the chemo does affect the heart but it can be a bit disconcerting listening to your changed heart rhythm. I haven't really had chest pain but do have soreness from the surgery site. Speak to your oncologist. I also had a scan checking for pulmonary embolism which was clear thank goodness. Hope everything settles for you soon. X
Posts.Title: chest pains during and after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, be guided by your oncologist. I asked ,mine about returning to work on good days and he said absolutely no way. I'm a nurse working in theatres with patients coming and going with MRSA etc. also, I'm finding the chemo pretty tough and can't even think about the energy required to work. I fully intend to return when my body feels able to cope, but until then I'm just coping with the treatment. Hope you get some support from your GP who may understand how chemo affects you both mentally and physically. X
Posts.Title: Fit notes

Posts.Content: Hi it does get better honest, it only lasts a few days then gradually subsides. Pain relief helps and you have to find which one is best for you. I take cocodamol but others are effective too see your GP if you can't cope or speak to your oncology nurse. Hope it settles soon x
Posts.Title: 1st tax and legs ache

Posts.Content: Thank goodness you have something that can be relieved. Hope you get home soon for-your extra special Christmas with your family. X
Posts.Title: fluid filled lung

Posts.Content: My Mother in law, has brought meals, cakes, shopped, rung every day. My Daughter, has rung and cleaned the house for me. My hubby, who listens to me rant and doesn't rant back. My GP who listens. My sister and my cousin who bring meals. Friends who take me out . You all know who you are and you are all super, wonderful, loving.......
Posts.Title: Just for fun , the lovely things people have done for you ?

Posts.Content: You are definitely not on your own Ethel. I just had to clear 10 cms of snow from car and drive to get to GP for a blood test re my chemo on Wed. My hospital is 23 miles away so don't even know if i'll make it Wed but I'll do my best. Maybe the suggestion of hospital transport could be explored? Hope all goes well. X
Posts.Title: What if I can't get to the hospital because of the snow for rads?

Posts.Content: Happy New Year, well done to all of you who have completed boot camp. may 2013 be the start of the rest your lives. For all the others about to start or mid boot camp, hope all goes well. I start tomorrow. New Year, new beginnings. This year we will all conquer cancer. Best wishes, hugs, love. I hope you receive the support you will all need. X
Posts.Title: new year onwards and upwards

Posts.Content: My what a caring daughter you are. Your Mum is so lucky to have your care and support. just being there for her is probably all she needs right now.Keep on this site I too am finding it very helpful. Try to relax a little your Mum is getting the best treatment for her cancer. x
Posts.Title: Help.

Posts.Content: Oh well done, brilliant achievement. I hope to get there too one day. You give me hope and a glance at the light at the end of this long dark tunnel. X
Posts.Title: Done it !!

Posts.Content: Great news, now you'll be able reassure others on the site. Try to get plenty of rest and enjoy watching hubby doing the chores. X
Posts.Title: update on my op yesterday which I was really anxious about
